awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Opportunities in Biophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in Biophysics at the University of Michigan (UM).  The site will support seven students for ten weeks of summer research each year.  The site will provide incoming students with an interdisciplinary research experience at the intersection of physics, chemistry, mathematics and the life sciences. The Biophysics Program at UM is one of few standalone biophysics programs in the US, created to foster multidisciplinary research and provide interdisciplinary undergraduate and graduate education. 

Biophysics is a very diverse field that spans and integrates experimental and theoretical work that is customarily assigned to mathematical, physical, chemical, biological or engineering sciences. Because of this wide scope of possible research experiences within Biophysics, some students may not realize the intellectual diversity of Biophysics. The site has developed an activity plan that focuses primarily on the research experience, but at the same time provides students with a condensed overview of sub-disciplines so that the student can experience the breath of this interdisciplinary discipline.  The core component of the program consists of research experiences where the students will participate in innovative scientific exploration with researchers and labs that match their interest. This core will be augmented by weekly research seminars and workshops to expose them to other relevant research topics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During its duration, the project invited 26 individuals from around the United States, typically finishing their sophomore or junior year, to participate in a summer research program in Biophysics at the University of Michigan. Majority of the students came from institutions that have limited research opportunities. Such an early experience is critical however for these students to even consider research career.  

We provided the incoming students with 10 weeks of truly unique, interdisciplinary research experience at the intersection of physics, chemistry, mathematics and the life sciences. In addition to the research experience we developed a series of professional training workshops to prepare the students for the life in academia. These included topic on academic professionalism, self-care, applying to grad school, how to shape your scientific pitch (talks), research ethics, imposter syndrome and mental wellness.

In addition to these workshops we held a workshop (that lasted whole duration of their summer program) to help them prepare personal and research statements that help them apply for fellowships and grad school programs.

Students also participated in events that allowed them to broaden their knowledge about research opportunities at a large research university. These included weekly research seminars and well as open houses organized by different graduate programs. 

We have supported more students than we planned (21) as during the pandemic we held the program online. The 2020 cohort was limited to two students that were doing research online. The 2021 cohort conducted most of their research online and visited UM only for a 2 week period towards the  end of the program. This allowed us to have in person symposium where the participating students presented their summer research results. During other years, as planned, students conducted their research in person and lived on campus.

We continue to keep in touch with our students after their program is done, and we know that vast majority of the students that completed our program does apply and join graduate programs. 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2024
Modified by: Michal R Zochowski
